0.title: Pest Watch – January (England)
items: Check overwintered brassicas for pigeon damage – net if needed.
Look for botrytis (grey mould) in damp cold frames.
Slugs hiding under pots – clear debris.

1.title: Pest Watch – February (England)
items: Aphids can appear in mild spells on broad beans.
Slugs active on salad leaves under cloches.
Mice eating pea/bean seeds in sheds or trays.

2.title: Pest Watch – March (England)
items: Flea beetle on brassica seedlings.
Slugs and snails emerging strongly.
Watch for damping-off in seed trays.

3.title: Pest Watch – April (England)
items: Cabbage root fly – protect seedlings with collars.
Carrot fly – use fleece or fine netting.
Slugs at night – trap and remove.

4.title: Pest Watch – May (England)
items: Aphids colonising beans and brassicas.
Cabbage white butterflies – eggs on brassicas.
Blackfly on broad beans – pinch out infested tips.

5.title: Pest Watch – June (England)
items: Potato blight risk increases – remove affected leaves.
Pea moth caterpillars – use mesh netting.
Whitefly on greenhouse tomatoes.

6.title: Pest Watch – July (England)
items: Powdery mildew on courgettes and squashes.
Tomato blight risk – water at soil level, ventilate.
Cabbage white caterpillars – hand remove.

7.title: Pest Watch – August (England)
items: Blight peak risk – potatoes and tomatoes.
Onion white rot – avoid replanting in affected soil.
Fruit flies around soft fruit – harvest promptly.

8.title: Pest Watch – September (England)
items: Slugs after rain – use beer traps, barriers.
Grey mould on late salads – improve airflow.
Rodents raiding stored crops.

9.title: Pest Watch – October (England)
items: Clubroot risk on brassicas – lime soil if needed.
Moulds in damp greenhouses/polytunnels.
Rodents around compost bins.

10.title: Pest Watch – November (England)
items: Check for slug damage under cloches.
Remove yellowing brassica leaves to deter pests.
Cover leafy veg from pigeons.

11.title: Pest Watch – December (England)
items: Protect stored root crops from mice.
Ventilate greenhouses to prevent mould.
Keep soil around overwintering garlic weed-free.
